column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: External assurance
column13: Monitoring regulatory compliance and obtaining external assurance are crucial aspects of Lynas Rare Earth's commitment to transparency, responsible business practices, and environmental stewardship.

column6: External assurance
column8: Department of Mines Industry Regulation and Safety reporting
column13: Lynas Rare Earth provides report requirements to the Department of Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, to specific protocols and provides accurate and timely information. This regulatory authority and a proactive approach to compliance will contribute to positive relationships and demonstrate Lynas Rare Earth's commitment to responsible mining practices.

column6: External assurance
column13: National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting (NGER) is a regulatory framework in Australia that requires certain corporations to report on their greenhouse gas emissions, energy consumption, and production. If Lynas Rare Earth is subject to NGER reporting, the Company must comply with the reporting requirements outlined by the Clean Energy Regulator.

column6: External assurance
column13: Tailings facility audits are critical to responsible mining practices, ensuring the safe management and containment of tailings produced during mining operations. Tailings are waste materials left after extracting valuable minerals from ore, and their proper containment is essential to prevent environmental harm.

column6: Explanation of the material topic and its Boundary
column7: Determining FY23 material issues comprised four key steps: research, identification, prioritization and validation. A cross-functional team conducted this process to ensure that we considered the full scope of the effects of our activities, both within our operations and externally, through interactions with investors, customers, communities, suppliers, the broader industry and others.

column6: The management approach and its components
column7: The FY23 Lynas Rare Earths Corporate Governance Statement outlines the skills and experiences each Board member contributes to their independence, tenure, responsibilities for the entire Board and its committees, and other significant Board positions.

column6: Evaluation of the management approach
column7: The Lynas Diversity Policy recognizes and champions diversity, ensuring a broad range of perspectives, experience and expertise. The Policy includes requirements for the Board to establish measurable objectives for achieving gender diversity in the composition of the Board, senior executives and the workforce generally and for the Board to assess, on an annual basis, the objectives and progress in achieving them.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: The Lynas Community Policy outlines our commitment to employing local people and sourcing from local businesses. The Lynas Way includes striving to create shared value through economic development and working with our host communities to address concerns and share the benefits of our operations.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: Lynas approach to local engagement includes information and consultation with local communities and partnerships with community organizations and educational institutions. Lynas engages and consults with local communities and other interested parties regarding environmental approvals and undertakes Social Impact Assessments to determine the effects of these operations on local communities.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: Lynas Rare Earth is used in future-facing technologies designed to lower emissions, reduce energy consumption, and improve efficiency, performance, speed, durability, and thermal stability. Lynas also collaborates with leading universities and research institutions in Australia and Malaysia on R&D projects.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: Lynas has actively developed international standards for the Rare Earth supply chain. It includes setting and publishing ISO traceability standards covering the rare earth supply chain from mine to magnets, participating in working group activities related to Sustainability standard development, and actively creating ISO standards for rare earth analytical methods.\t

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: As announced on 21 June 2023, Lynas was awarded a $20 million grant as part of the Australian Government's Modern Manufacturing Initiative Manufacturing Integration Stream. The grant will develop a new capability to process apatite-rich ores from the Mt Weld ore body through a newly developed process containing two circuits for removing apatite.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: Lynas announced signing an approximately US$258 million follow-on contract with the United States (U.S.) Department of Defense (DoD) for constructing the Heavy Rare Earths component of the Lynas U.S. Rare Earths Processing Facility in Texas. The new Facility will be a commercial facility. It will help strengthen supply chain resilience for responsibly produced rare earth as inputs to the United States' burgeoning high-tech industry and the U.S. and allied nations' national security needs.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: Lynas recognizes that local community support and acceptance is critical to the success of our operations. We are proud to have earned the trust of our local communities in the Kuantan area of Malaysia by operating our plant safely for over 10 years and being a valued employer and active member of our local communities.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column7: Drawing on Lynas Life Cycle Assessment (LCA), the most significant contributions to Scope 3 emissions in the value chain were identified as raw chemicals inputs to production. In FY23, Lynas evaluated the emissions from business travel.

column6: Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans

Ratios of standard entry level wage by gender compared to local minimum wage
Proportion of senior management hired from the local community
column7: Lynas hired 2 senior managers from Malaysian nationalities and 7 senior management employees from Australian nationalities.

column6: Infrastructure investments and services supported
Significant indirect economic impacts
column7: Lynas focuses on social investment in health and wellness, education and employment, and supporting vulnerable community members. In FY23, direct community investment and related expenditures across Lynas operations were approximately $0.6m plus employee volunteering hours.

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column7: In FY23, 88% of inputs were procured at the local (i.e. Western Australia) or country (Malaysia) level across the Company'sCompany's operating sites.

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column13: In FY23, Lynas continued to work through Transparency International's U.K. guidance on anti-bribery and corruption best practices for companies to identify opportunities to improve our anti-bribery and corruption program. It included the annual staff Code of Conduct and anti-bribery and corruption training undertaken during the year.

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: The Lynas Whistleblower Policy contains protections and confidentiality provisions for whistleblowers, consistent with applicable legislation, and contact details for the independently operated Disclosure Line. Lynas encourage their people and communities to report any concerns or breaches of policies, and Lynas has an independently run, confidential Disclosure Line in place for our personnel, business and communities.

Energy consumption within the organization
column7: Energy consumption within the organization's activities on a net basis is 470.749 Mwh.

column6: Energy consumption outside of the organization
Energy intensity
column13: As noted above, as part of the Mt Weld expansion project, a transition from the current diesel power station to a gas-renewable hybrid power station is planned to reduce the intensity of GHG emissions. A tender was released for the gas-hybrid power station in FY23, and an early works tender was awarded. Lynas intends to finalize contract negotiations for the gas-hybrid power station in FY24.
